column2: The Pancasila faith is a relatively new addition to the island of Indonesia. Claiming to follow the teachings of their grand antediluvian leader Sukarno and acting more as a set of philosophical and political beliefs rather than a religion, its adherents believe themselves to be the true continuation of the old world state of Indonesia. All Pancasila rulers consider themselves mere governors in a great Indonesia, regardless if they act independently or not. Those who believe in Pancasila claim that yang Maha Esa gave Sukarno the Five Principles and Thirty-Seven Commandments so that he could lead the people of Indonesia against the forces of wickedness who enslaved the people of Indonesia during his time and lead Indonesia into an age of peace and unity, which they could once again bring if they follow the Principles and Laws. Its followers are very tolerant of any monotheistic religion, seeing them as yet another aspect of yang Maha Esa and are quite charitable to the commoners as the Fifth Principle demands social justice for all Indonesians.
The Five Principles and Thirty-Seven Commandments

The Concordianist Church considers itself the sole legitimate successor of the greatest polity the Old World had ever seen - Europa itself. From the days of Charlemagne all the way to the Event, wise Europa functioned as one, unified in diversity. Though Europa has since fallen, they believe she is destined to rise again, as she has many times before. Thus, the Concordianists do not believe it is the destiny of any one man to unite the whole continent by his hand, but rather the collective destiny of all of Europe, once they come to realise their strength in unity. Guided by the many Fathers of Europe, such as Plato, Kant, and Hegel, who themselves have been guided by the divine hand of Providence, the Concordianists, though fallen far from grace, now comprise some of the greatest artists and philosophers in post-Event Europe. Throughout many courts of Europe can be heard the odes to the glory of Europa Regina, reinforcing the fact that though she may have ceased to exist as a polity, she forever lingers on as an idea in the hearts of men. Those whose souls have been touched by the pan-European ideals of the Concordianists venture to Brussels, where Europa first embodied herself as an angel atop a white bull, and a grand cathedral was built atop the hill where the old institutions are buried. Together, they work towards the return of a unified Europa, the Daughter of Elysium.

A form of Islam native to the Indian subcontinent. Ahmadi Muslims believe that a messianic figure known as the Mahdi, named Ahmad, came down to India before the Event, announcing that the people must repent and turn back to the True Islam, or else be destroyed. To those who accepted him he showed the new way of peace, and proclaimed that Islam would no longer be spread by the sword, but by more peaceful means. To those who rejected him, he issued condemnations. The Event then fell upon the people for their lack of faith, while the chosen people remained safe, hidden from the wrath. Now, under the guidance of their Caliph, the Ahmadiyya go forth once again, to preach the religion of peace to every corner of the ruined world.

One of the first organised religions founded after the Event, Amaitism is a syncretic faith founded by the prophet Amaité in southern California. Amaitists claim that their prophet was formerly a Zoroastrian, given divine revelation by Ahura Mazda. Amaitism states that Ahura Mazda consists of a trinity, with the great prophets of history - Zoroaster, Jesus and Buddha - being emanations of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit respectively.  Jesus is the Son of God, whose great sacrifice removed the original sin from mankind, and Zoroaster and Buddha are prophets who spent their days teaching the common man how to enter Heaven by escaping the cycle of rebirth that all humans are otherwise destined for. For each aspect of the Trinity, Ahura Mazda created a counter - forces of chaos meant to bring balance. Angra Mainyu created the material world, Satan created the sins of man and Mara created the cycle of rebirth. Without each divine aspect having its opposite, the world cannot function. Amaitists also believe non-believers can enter heaven, though they have a harder time doing so by rejecting the teachings of Amaité, as it was revealed to them that the great religions of the world are merely single aspects of a single God's plan. Depictions of Amaité are forbidden, the line being drawn at an androgynous figure with a burning face, as they were never an emanation of God, merely a messenger. As such, their final request was for them to be forgotten, not wanting to be deified themselves.

Sarnaism is a folk religion practised primarily by the Kurukh and Munda peoples and spread throughout the Chota Nagpur plateau in eastern India. Claiming to be an ancient belief system existing since time immemorial, Sarnaism, known locally as Sarna Dhorom and to outsiders as the Religion of the Holy Woods, is a nature worshipping pagan faith largely detached from surrounding Hindu and Abrahamic religions. Though syncretism is commonplace, Sarnaists reject the Varna system and ignore any foreign religious texts, instead turning inwards, focusing on protecting and nurturing the nature around them. Having a vast and inconsistent amount of deities and spirits, the most frequently worshipped supreme creator is the Sun, known as Dharmes, a force of unquestionable good. The sacred Sarna grove is of especial importance, and it is believed the groves are the abode of Chala Pachchho, a powerful female deity commonly identified as a mother goddess of earth and nature. Once a year Sarnaists observe the Sarhul festival, a three day period of celebration in which adherents celebrate marriage between the Earth and the Sun and offer sacrifices to village deities.

Sarnaists reject the Varna system and foreign religious texts, instead following a codified set of deities and rituals. The supreme deity of the Sarna religion is the Sun god Dharmes, who is believed to be the force of unquestionable good in the world, hampered only by human vices. Sarnaists believe that the old world was struck down by Dharmes as punishment for mankind's destruction of nature, and consider it their main duty to preserve and protect nature from those who wish to exploit and destroy it. Once a year Sarnaists observe the Sarhul festival, a three day period of celebration in which priests called Pahan offer sacrifices to the mother goddess Chala Pachchho and ancestral spirits, celebrating marriage between the Earth and the Sun.

Islam in China goes by many names - "Orthodox religion", "Cubic religion" or simply "Hui religion", but one word that is used by its followers to exemplify its virtues is "Qingzhenjiao", or the "Pure and True Religion". Due to its isolation from the wider ummah by successive Chinese governments, the Muslims of China have adopted peculiar practices influenced by the local Confucian and Daoist philosophies and other new Chinese religious traditions, such as ancestor veneration and a generally Confucian social outlook. In fact, many Muslims in China consider Confucius on par with the Prophet Muhammad, dubbing him the "Sage of the East" as opposed to the Prophet's status as the "Sage of the West". They will often translate Islamic concepts using Confucian terminology, culminating in the near-syncreticism of Confucianism and Islam present in many of their religious works, such as the Han Kitab, or the use of Taoist clothes by certain members of their Sufi orders.

Ak Jang is an indigenous religion that flourished among the Altai people of Russia's Altai Republic during the 1900s. The Russian Empire was suspicious of the movement's potential to stir up native unrest and perhaps involve outside powers and thus suppressed it. The religion was originally millenarian, charismatic and anti shamanic, the movement gradually lost most of these qualities becoming increasingly routine, institutionalized and accommodating itself to the pre existing Altaian folk religion. It is derived from a combination of Tengriism, Buddhism and Khurmaztism.

It is notable for syncretising with christianity and Islam shortly prior to the event, furthermore it is notable for its ancestor worship and the fact that it was one of the few remaining megalithic religions prior to the event, with families often taking on debt to expand their familial cairns.

Wunggurr is a name denoting the underlying lifeforce of the world among the Indigenous nations of the Kimberley. To the believers in the Wunggurr, their land was created by Wolaro, a deity who alone divided the world into two moieties - Bramalar and Bronor. He told the animals, rocks, plants and ancestor spirits to which moeity they would belong to, passing down the male line. Spirits known as Wandjina also play an important role among the Kimberley Clans. The Wandjina are protective and totemic spirits contained within rock paintings who are maintained and repainted by local peoples. They appear in many of the creation stories of the land. Additionally, there is reverence for the Rainbow Serpent Lumuru, who is a servant to Wolaro. Lumuru delivers spirit-children into the womb of women, making them pregnant, and transforming said spirit into flesh and blood.

One of the native surviving folkloric religions on the island of sulawasi its largest group of adherents are to be found amongst the Torajan people. The religion believes in a variety of dieties though all are in some manner considered ancestors to the human population of earth. The world is divided into the underworld, the Earth and heaven, the ancestors of humans having descended from heaven in ancient times. The earthly authority, whose words and actions should be cleaved to both in life and death , is called a To Minaa. Aluk is not just a belief system, it is a combination of law, religion, and habit. Aluk governs social life, agricultural practices, and ancestral rituals. The details of aluk may vary from one village to another. One common law is the requirement that death and life rituals be separated. Torajans believe that performing death rituals might ruin their corpses if combined with life rituals. The two rituals are equally important. Now that the faith has been reformed it is impossible to say the direction it will take.

Originating in the Americas, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (commonly referred to as Mormons) spread to the Old World/The Pacific by missionary efforts long before the Event. Despite being cut off from contact with the rest of the church by the Event, the Mormon faithful have endured in either small pockets or wandering congregations scattered across Eurasia. While considering themselves Christians, due to their heterodox beliefs (including a non-Trinitarian nature of God, an open canon of scripture, and that the Christian Church needed to be restored due to apostasy) few faiths agree and consider them entirely seperate. These circumstances have made it difficult for any large population of Mormons to gather in one place for long, and so many content themselves to simply live and preach their faith until a day comes where they can find a homeland for themselves.

Rastafari is the religion of the Rastas, founded in Jamaica. They are worshippers of Jah, the God of all. According to them, the Event was caused by the decadent forces of Babylon getting struck down by Jah, in the form of Ras Tafari, the manifestation of Jah and the Emperor of Zion. The Rastafari hold that after the Event, Ras Tafari returned to Jah, leaving behind Zion as the new paradise on Earth, ruled by the faithful. Many Rastas believe it is now their duty to return to Zion, their promised land, though many others hold they are also meant to spread Jah's love to all corners of the world, including what remains of Babylon.\nThe Rastas believe Jah is present in every person, a concept they call "I and I", expressing the connection between all people by Jah. Rastas strictly adhere to the concept they call livity, which means leading a righteous life in order to gain awareness and oneness with Jah, the primary goal in a Rasta's life. To that extent, livity means frequent prayer, meditation, oneness with nature, and most important of all, oneness and love for others. Their prayers are often very mystical, involving the use of psychedelic herbs and becoming aware of oneness with Jah. Lacking formal hierarchy or doctrine, the Rastafari are quite disunited in their beliefs, being divided into three main denominations, or "Mansions" - the Bobo Ashanti, the Nyabinghi Order, and the Twelve Tribes of Israel, each with their own distinct doctrines, though they are united by their love of Jah. In the old world the religion is primarily found in various American Quarters of the Nigerian Empire, across its various cities, the largest being in Lagos, the Imperial capital.

Agama Tirta is a Hindu faith practised primarily by the people of the island of Bali. Believed to be the religion of Bali since time immemorial, folk legends claim it is the ancestral faith of all Nusantara, having already been reduced to obscurity before the Event. Formally monotheistic, Balinese worship is focused primarily on a supreme being called Acintya, also known as Sang Hyang Tunggai or Sang Hyang Widi Wasa. Worship of the Trimurti is commonplace, whom they consider to be manifestations of Acintya, occasionally identified as Shiva or Siwa-Sadasiwa-Paramasiwa. Deities not found in Indian Hinduism are also present. Bali Hindus still adhere to the varna system.
Emerged from the mixing between the Hellenic and Sea Creed religions, Poseidonians hold the belief that Poseidon, god of the seas, is the rightful heir to the Olympian pantheon.

The Girondins are a deistic faith that believes the many gods of Europe are merely individual facets of a single great, incomprehensible Architect of Creation, who made man in his image spiritually, but not physically. Because man is of the Creator, it is also man who is to rule over other men, with those of the First Estate being chosen by the Creator to rule. However, should a monarch fall to his basal desires, and fail to uphold the duties and virtues bestowed upon him by God, it is the duty of the Third Estate to dethrone him and feed him to Madame Guillotine. It is in this way that Girondists uphold the balance of the universe, for it was Madame Guillotine who brought the Event once every ruler on Earth was a corrupt tyrant. The three archangels of God - Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity, embody the principles a just and righteous ruler is to live by, and are also those who bring the Third Estate to depose a tyrant. Though once a widespread religion in France, the rise of Númenor and Novelism has seen it fall by the wayside and incorporate heavy syncretism with their Novelist cousins, the two religions slowly but surely blending into one.

Kalikula, meaning "Family of Kali" is the name for the Shaktist tradition of Kali worship most prevalent in northeastern India. Worship is focused on the goddess Kali as the main and most important manifestation of Brahman. Influenced by the teachings of the pre-Event guru Ramakrishna, modern Kali worship largely emphasises devotion (bhakti) over ritual, and as a result brahmin influence has greatly dropped after the Event. Other than Kali, worshipped deities include the Mahavidyas, Kaumari, Chandi, Durga, and many more regional gods and goddesses. Kali as the Supreme Being is considered both the loving mother of her children and their fierce guardian, and by extent the destroyer of evil. Worship is most often communal and carried out through festivals such as Kali Puja.

The Nobelian Hermetic Order is an occult hermetic society dedicated to uncovering the secrets of the Old World. Named after the legendary founder of their Order, Alfred Nobel, the Nobelians believe the Old World was home to master alchemists - their discovery of the famed philosopher's stone led to the creation of many advanced technologies - flying contraptions, machine computers, the perpetuum mobile - most now being buried and difficult, if not impossible, to recreate. However, their failure to find the universal panacea, the cure of all disease, led to their downfall, with plague wiping the slate of the Old World clean. Now, the Nobelians are masters in the arts of alchemy, chemistry, medicine, archaeology, and everything in between, seeking to restore old lost knowledge, and educate many in the arts of their ways in their lavish Old World universities. They are guided by Hermes, the ancient god of wisdom, and will stop at nothing to right the wrongs of the Old World before it is too late to prevent another Event.

Arcencism, colloquially called Jeannism, is a sect of French Catholicism that has developed a cult-like following of Jeanne d'Arc. According to legend, Jeanne led France to victory against the worshippers of the wicked Queen long before the Event in the fabled Siege of Orléans. She was given the sword Joyeuse by the angel Marianne, which she used to smite the Queen as instructed by Saint Michael in a battle of Heaven and Earth. Vengeful, the Queen's worshippers made a pact with Satan, bewitching the Pope into branding Jeanne as a heretic, executing her and tarnishing her legacy for years to come.\nThough the Church has since absolved Jeanne and declared her a Saint, her loyal followers haven't forgotten the treachery committed against her by Albion and the Papists, and years of tension in the post-Event world led to the formal excommunication of the Jeannist leaders and the religion being declared heretical. Even though the Catholic Church in France has long since met its end, the Jeannists have held steadfast in their fortresses, attracting more people than ever to their Crusade after the British took over Northern France, seeking to banish Albion and their resurrected Demon-Queen from the mainland and into the sea.

Deha Tatta, meaning "truth in the body", is the name of the central theme and purpose of the songs of the Bauls. Bauls are the mystic troubadours of eastern India, who perform enigmatic songs and spread a message of love. Their music and poetry, called Baul sangeet, preaches about finding relationship with God and achieving spiritual liberation, seeking divinity within each person. They believe one should always be searching for Moner Manush - the "Man of their Heart", or the divine spirit of God manifested inside the body. Followers of Deha Tatta are as such devoted to Sadhana, the spiritual practice of transcending material things through purified love and devotion. The Bauls themselves come from various backgrounds, both from within the religion and from neighbouring religions like Islam and Hinduism. This act of coming together to preach love and mysticism has resulted in a unique blend of religions that has taken over Bengal since the Event.

It did not take long in the chaos surrounding the event for banditry, chaos, and upstart cults to overtake the Russian Orthodox Church in the far east. Priests, monks, and the few remaining believers found themselves struggling to hold onto their lives and faith, the believers struggled to preserve what artifacts and texts they could as Cathedrals were ransacked, converted, or destroyed. The remaining believers found refuge within a range of communities deep in the Siberian far east finding a home where they could build new monasteries and in their isolation developed several distinct interpretations of the bible. The Far East Church differs from standard Orthodox Theology with their adoption of a far more mystical and esoteric outlook on God and heaven with an emphasis on the unknowability of God who they refer to only indirectly using terms such as "the one" or "the whole". The Far east church also developed a strong ascetic tradition with numerous Monks or Saints performing public mortification of the flesh in order to sever their connection to the sinful material world and contemplate the infinite nature of the mind of the One, Such Mortification commonly includes self immolation as well as a revival of the Stylite traditions where a Monk will live on tall pillars or on tree tops meditating where they contemplate the One and preach their revelations to their community until their death. Vostokists believe that in death all souls are required to be purified for some time, and that in this state of purification all souls are connected and may influence each other. Vostokists believe that the event was caused due to an overabundance of sinful souls whoch has caused mankind's connection to God to be severed causing a backflow of sinful thought to destroy the world and all subsequent souls since then to enter a state of disconnect from God dooming them to a state of existence without connection to the One: Hell. Vostokists believe that it is the goal of the Saints to redeem the collective soul of mankind and restore mankind's divine link to God and to combat the devil who they believe exists within the collective evil thoughts and sins of all mankind seeking to doom all to an eternity without The Ones guidance once they are resurrected on the day of judgement.

One of the many faiths that survived the great calamity in France, Raëlism traces its roots back to the mythical pre-Event prophet known as Raël. The religion teaches that humanity was designed and created by an extraterrestrial race known as the Elohim. This was revealed to Raël by one of these creatures named Eru L'Auteur, who explained to him the truth of the universe. Claiming to be the leader of the Elohim and the creator of humanity, he reveals that, throughout all of history, he had created a total of 40 Elohim-human hybrids on Earth, who served humanity as prophets - among them being The Buddha, Jesus Christ, Charlemagne, and Napoleon, with Raël himself being the 40th and final prophet. Raëlians claim that the world entered its current age, the Age of Destruction, in the pre-Event year of 1945, with an event called "the Atomic Bombing", in which a faraway planet called Hiroshima was annihilated by a great explosion caused by humans, after which humanity turned on each other and became dedicated to its own destruction, culminating in the Event itself and their near-total extinction.

They recognise the hell of war, but believe there must be those that are prepared to make a sacrifice for the good of others, and those that lay down their lives are well remembered in yearly Mournings and elaborate cenotaphs.

The Bahá'í Faith is a faith based on the teachings of the antediluvian prophets Báb, and his successor Bahá'u'lláh. They believe in a universalist world view of religion, claiming that there is one God, who is incomprehensible, and whose will has been and will be manifested throughout time in an endless series of revelations and theophanies given to the prophets of man. These Manifestations of God have been revealed to prophets progressively throughout history, unifying humanity in purpose, with interpretations differing according to societal needs. As a result, the Bahá'í are ardent advocates of world peace and unity, with their single greatest goal being that of a single world order where everyone can prosper, regardless of their race, nation, or beliefs.

Born in antiquity, Baptism is a strain of Protestantism that is highly charismatic and vigorous. It believes that only adult believers should be baptised, and that too by full bodily immersion in water. They reject most of the Catholic sacraments and follow a Congregational model of Church governance. Baptists after the Event became isolated from their homeland in America, and mostly exist as religious minorities throughout Asia due to prior missionaries evangelizing heavily there. In northeastern India, they became a majority and established the first Baptist kingdom in the Old World. In other areas, smaller Baptist congregations desperately fight for survival.

The Bezpopovtsy, meaning the Priestless, are a strain of the Old Believer faithful that still stick to their old ways. Having no formal priestly hierarchy, or priests at all for that matter, the Bezpopovtsy completely reject even what little authority the First Hierarch has, instead holding local sermons with the position of priest being most often filled by family or village patriarchs. This lack of organisation has led to the festering of some heterodox practices, such as local scripture, local spirit worship, and most egregiously, self-immolation.

The Penitente are a group of Sevillianists who preach that humanity, and especially the Spanish people, are full of guilt and do not deserve salvation. They preach that the only hope to avoid eternal damnation is to accept one's guilt and do penance in order to be absolved by the Lord when he sees sincere repentance. Penances can be very varied, including self-flagellation, crucifixion, etc., but all of them usually coincide in that the penitent must suffer great pain during the penance so that his guilt can be absolved. All this is due to the fact that long before the event, when brothers were killing each other in a supposed holy war, a false prophet arose. This false prophet was none other than the antichrist who deceived the people of Spain that he had been sent by God Himself to restore the worship of the Lord and eradicate the wicked and degenerate from this land. The church in Spain instead of seeing through the lies of the antichrist, blinded by their hatred, wholeheartedly supported the antichrist, shepherding the people of Spain straight into the jaws of the beast. The antichrist demanded from the people their praise for being sent by god under threat of death for anyone who refused, the slaughter was such that he founded lakes and rivers throughout Spain with the blood of his victims. Fortunately the Lord did not abandon his people and sent his archangel Raphael to kill the antichrist, after which he punished the world with the event.

A faith originating in the wake of the event in the previously extremely atheistic nation of Czechia, Osvicenism is a fusion of both Christian and Buddhist beliefs which had grown significantly in popularity within the nation. Founded by a Czech Buddhist Monk who had been raised a Catholic, he found a way to unite his disparate beliefs together under one system which appealed to the people across Czechia and Goralia. Later this system of belief would spread east by several Monks to the Buddhists of Kalmykia, converting many and becoming a stronghold of the faith. It espouses that while it was to the Buddha that God revealed how one may ascend to heaven, it was only available to the most ascetic of monks, it was only through the sacrifice of Christ that this pathway was made open to all. It views sins such as Pride or Lust as faults which must be overcome by meditation on their meaning and the emotional state which they cause. Only by conquering these faults across multiple lifespans may a person purify themselves and therefore escape the cycle of Birth, Death, Purgatory and Rebirth which all but the most ascetic monks are trapped within. Those ascetics are close to fulfilling their escape to heaven where they will join God as saints.

Bailianjiao or "The Faith of the White Lotus" is a religion of syncretic Buddhist-Manichean origin which spent centuries underground throughout Chinese society only having re-emerged following the event. It awaits the arrival of the Lord of Light and wishes to take control of China to prepare the way for his arrival. Moni is believed to have been the most recent reincarnation of the Lord of Light, other reincarnations include the Buddha, Zoroaster and Jesus. Devout practitioners of this faith practice a vegetarian diet. The Jade Emperor, Sapphire Didact and Ruby Chairmen are seen as evil deities due to their relationship with the successive Chinese states which oppressed those of the White Lotus.

Mojiao is the religion of most Zhuang people. While it has a supreme god, the creator Bu Luotuo, numerous other deities are venerated as well. It has a three-element-theory of the universe: sky, earth and water. Mojiao is animistic, teaching that spirits are present in everything. Moism developed from the prehistoric beliefs of the Zhuang people and it also has similarities to Chinese folk religion, and has developed similar doctrines to Buddhism and Daojiao, in the process of competition with the influence of these religions on Zhuang culture. Mojiao varies from region to region.

Wujiao refers to the various shamanic religious traditions of the Sinitic populations of China. Chinese shamanism is intrinsic to Chinese folk religion and is fairly diverse. Various rituals and traditions are rooted in this belief system, such as Ritual Masters being identified as Wu by outsiders, though most adherents don't self-identify as such. In addition, Daojiao developed partially from Wujiao, as it focused around the pursuit of a long life, or the status of becoming a Xian, otherwise known as a holy man. Having been suppressed and stigmatized in pre-Event China, the religion post-Event had experienced a small revival but remains heavily fragmented. Wuists have generally opted to remain outside of the Daojiao-Liehuo-Sanminshuyi debate regarding the war in Heaven.

Wujiao refers to the shamanic religious traditions of the Sinitic populations of China. Having undergone a great reformation, the Reformed Wuist faith has a semi-codified list of proper rituals and beliefs by combining the most popular ones together, as well as firmly establishing the roles of the Ritual Masters, or Wu as they are sometimes called. Although initially hesitant to participate in the Daojiao-Liehuo-Sanminzhuyi debate, the Reformed Wuists are now actively engaging in such matters. Depending on who leads the faith, it is impossible to say the direction Wuism will take in this regard.

After the Event that struck the world, the Catholic faithful of Asia lost all contact with Rome. Chaos ensued after the acknowledgement of this fact as panicked church leaders and archbishops all around Asia try to re-establish contact with Rome. It took years of looking for and reading rotten antediluvian documents from the years before the Event for the procedure on what to do if this scenario happens. At last, the various archbishops of Asia knew what to do, and with the knowledge from the documents and support from other archbishops around Asia during the First Council of Manila, the former Archbishop of Manila has been declared Patriarch of Asia.

Even before the Event, some schismatic Filipinos wanted to have a seperate Filipino Catholic Church separate from Rome, akin to the Church of England, more known as the Anglicans. Now with the chaos of the Event, the Aglipayans, more centralized thanks to the severed connection of the Philippines and Rome, are now more vocal than ever with their goal of an independent Philippine Church separate from Rome.

Originating in the Philippines, the El Shaddai are a herbalistic group that believes in folk healing with herbs and the power of God. Their heavy usage of herbs and a questionable amount of practices foreign to the Katoliko faith make the El Shaddai popular amongst people who want to syncretize Catholicism and their various traditions.

The Sea Creed faith is more a loose group of superstitions from the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The corsairs of those seas hold together their crews through the fear inspired by the risks of going against the Code of the Sea, and of course against their ruler. Most rulers turn a blind eye on the acts and rituals of the Sea Creed, especially because the Corsairs bring in a fair profit.

The Sea Creed in the North Atlantic tends to favour a much different set of beliefs compared to warmer shores. Calling themselves "children of Ragnarök", the vikings of the northern seas hold that the Event was Ragnarök come to end the world. The prophecies foretold came true one by one, with the Old Gods being slain in the great calamity. The world serpent Jörmungandur poisoned the water and sky and ended life as the Old World knew it alongside Surtur and Fenrir. The world survived their onslaught though, and though the Old Gods perished in their twilight, their kindred came to inherit their roles and end Ragnarök. Thus, the New World is watched over by Baldur and Hod, who lead a new pantheon of benevolent deities, while the Old Gods are all either dead or mere husks of their former selves. They are often malevolent and considered signs of bad luck, unable to let go of a world that moved on.

Born long before the Event in the mountains of Switzerland, the Reformed Churches follow the Protestant tradition as laid down by the great sage Calvin and his like-minded reformers. The Calvinists strongly believe in the concept of predestination, in which the salvation of men is pre-determined by God long before their judgement. This belief extends to the question of rule, with many Calvinists believing that he who is not destined to go to Heaven is not destined to rule either.\nThe Church itself was supposedly never claimed by the fires of the Event, being saved by the legendary Emperor Jürgén from destruction. The Council of Geneva marked a turning point during those early days of the deluge, establishing Geneva as the home of the Church's Elder and the Calvinist Theocracy as the only valid form of temporal government. Soon after, the rest of the European Reformed Churches were brought back into the fold, and since then the Calvinists have been organising, preparing to sally forth from their mountains and retake what is rightfully theirs.

The Roman Catholic Church survived through the Event, like it did through so many other crises, great and small. It did not, however, come out unscathed. Though the state of the Church during the Event is murky at best, the Holy See was officially restored in the Year 2100, with the Keys of Heaven being given to Saint Adalbertus, the first legitimate successor to pre-Event Pope John Paul II. The Church has had many losses, losing large swathes of territory to pagans, heretics, and idolators, as well as suffering from the Sevillian Schism, where the faithful of Spain flocked to a rival Pope in Seville. Since then, the true Holy See has adapted to the post-Event world accordingly, allowing the marriage of priests and the appointment of female deacons to make up for the massive loss of life during the Event, as well as recognising a variety of local rites and the celebration of Vernacular Mass. Now, the Church may finally, for the first time in a long time, have the upper hand against its neighbours, and only time may tell if it will survive in this new changing world, as it has for countless millennia.

A ancient faith first revived on the Aran islands of Ireland, spreading to the nearby Galway, Mayo and Sligo. While not a direct successor, it has survived somewhat in the background of Ireland's long Christianization. It worships the spirits which inhabit all places in the world, having returned from the otherworld where they were banished by the Christian Saint Patrick. The event destroyed the barriers he put in place allowing the spirits to return once again. Of particular worship are water spirits as they give life. The ruler of these fae is Lir, Old King of the Sea, and his Swan children. The rulers of this faith are also Draoithe themselves and as such are permitted to directly hold temples.

Genevism is a Calvinist movement founded, according to legend, right after the Event during the reign of Emperor Jürgen the Holy. The Genevists are named after the Council of Geneva, in which all Calvinist priests in Europe attended. The Council announced the proclamation of the Calvinist Theocracy as the official form of governance for the Alpereich, which caused a number of priests to storm out, leading to their excommunication and the subsequent founding of the Genevese Church. Following this schism, the Genevese Church eventually took more radical stances regarding Calvinist politics, advocating for total separation of the realm of God and the realms of men. According to the Genevese, all of God's laws cannot be realistically enforced on Earth, and as such Theocracy cannot be the ideal way to govern as it is fundamentally flawed. Though their popularity has waned in the years after the Council, relegating them to near obscurity, Genevese thought may yet be revived once theocratic rule fails the Calvinist faithful.

This distinct sect of Judaism, practiced by the Betah Israeli Jews of Ethiopia has too survived the Event. Their Biblical texts have a few additions to the usual Jewish Bible. After the event, several old customs were revived, such as the unique monastic traditions that differ from the traditions of other Jews.

Zoroastrians worship Ahura Mazda, the uncreated God, as proclaimed by the ancient Iranian prophet Zoroaster. It was the official religion of all Persian empires (except the Hellenic Seleucid Empire) until the Muslim conquest of the Sassanid Empire in 651. The ancient form of the religion involved great sacred hill top fires and the exposure of dead bodies to scavenger birds for cleansing, while the modern form of this religion instead mainly focuses on the following of its primary creed, "Good Thoughts, Good Deeds, Good Words." As such, they are very generous and charitable despite the fact their religion has seriously declined in its number of adherents. The two largest surviving communities can be found in central Iran and Western India, though there was an attempt at revival in the Yarsani Kingdom of Kurdistan in recent history.

Based on a collection of texts uncovered by a Zoroastrian Priest in late 23rd century Tajikistan. This faith holds that the god of time Zorvan is father to both Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu and that Zorvan guides humans destiny through various celestial implements. One key difference between this sect and its ancient forebearer is that it contends that Humans must have free will otherwise the command by Ahura Mazda to do good is pointless, thus a divine being would not state such. The faith looks slightly more favourably on Angra Mainyu than traditional Zoroastrianism due to him being one of Zorvan's sons. Additionally they believe that Zorvan's sons must both exist for there to be a universal balance, they believe that there can be no good without evil and no order without chaos to compare it to, while Ahura Mazda is the sibling worthy of worship Angra Mainyu should be respected for the role he plays in the natural order of Zorvan's weave. Because of these beliefs it was driven from its Tajik homeland by its fellow Zoroastrians and the religion found popularity amongst the Sarikoli. The religion generally speaking is not aggressive and if not for it's aggressive neighbours would continue residing amongst its mountain tribes.

Dating back to the early days of Islam, the Qurani believe that Islamic law and guidance should only be based on the Koran, thus opposing any religious authority of the hadiths as well as caliphs. It is their belief that God's message in the Koran is clear and complete as is and that it can be fully understood without referencing outside scriptures. In the post Event era, the Qurani are heavily persecuted and often branded as apostates. They themselves view other Muslims as corrupted and seek to bring Islam back to its original form.

Pusaka, meaning Heirloom, is a term for a syncretic school of Sunni that has gained a widespread following in the lands of Nusantara. Born from a combination of Islam and various Indonesian and Malay native beliefs, spirituality, mysticism and shamanism have an important role in the Pusaka faith. Shamans, known as the dukun to Indonesians and the bomoh to the Malay, have an important role in society, considered to be healers and diviners. Weather shamans, known as the pawang, are believed to control the weather and tame wild beasts. There is a special emphasis on ancestral heirlooms, which are believed to house the spirits of ancestors and must be protected, and can give their owners extraordinary powers. Other than venerating the spirits of ancestors, the Pusaka also believe in a wide variety of supernatural entities, ranging from ghosts, known as the hantu, to imps, goblins, and familiars, all of which would either aid them or harm them through contracts and witchcraft. Despite incorporating a large amount of native beliefs and being denounced by mainstream Muslims as blasphemers and profaners, the Pusaka still firmly consider themselves Muslim, believing that only a powerful and pious Sultan can firmly unite Nusantara once more.

Santri is an Islamic sect originating in Nusantara. It is named after students that pursue Islamic religious education in a "pesantren", a type of religious school which played a major role in the spread of Islam within the region. Largely the same as pre-Event orthodox Sunni Islam, the Santri sect has managed to largely avoid internal religious conflict and major distortions to theology through adaptation of local Malay folklore and practices to fit Islam instead of the other way around. Despite outward insistence on religious cohesion and Shafi'i legalism, private worship of Santri Islam tends to have many esoteric Sufist and mystic rituals, including the veneration of ancestral and nature spirits and the religious consumption of cannabis. Nonetheless, the Santri sect still stands tall as the most powerful faith in Nusantara, a position that comes with a theological battle against the syncretic Pusaka sect, a faith which threatens to erase Santri way of life from the history books.

Navayana is a school of Buddhism founded in the decades leading up to the event. Its founder, Bhimrao Ambedkar was born a Hindu, but however following his study of the Buddha's teachings he became convinced of its truth. He found that all currently existing schools of Buddhism had become overly esoteric and no longer thought the Buddha's lessons as he would have wished them. As such he created the "Buddh aur unaka dhamm" which was a recounting of the Buddha's teachings and life with the addition of commentaries added by Ambedkar. This was meant to remove some of the esotericism which had developed in the previously existing sects.

A heresy spawned from just before the event from the theology of Father Matta El Meskeen. He came to blows with the Coptic papacy over the nature of original versus personal sin and the importance of personal faith in god over that of the collective faith in the church. He believed Original sin prior to Jesus was something that an individual could overcome through good deeds and that after the crucifixion one could overcome original sin by either accepting Jesus as their savior or through their own good deeds. As such Mattaists are extremely charitable to their impoverished citizens. He also believed in the total separation of the church and the state such that the church would not interfere with state policies. Overall the importance he placed on personal faith and his critiques of the Coptic church led to Mattaists believing post event that they no longer needed a papacy to govern them.

The Neo-Fraticelli, or 'New Little Brethren', is a Catholic heresy that was inspired by records of a medieval heresy of the same name. It is devoted to poverty and asceticism - especially for men of the cloth. Fraticelli heretics are violently opposed to Church wealth and displays of opulence among the populace. This is due to Mammon Prince of Greed being viewed as the demon King of the old world, he grew so powerful as to overthrow Lucifer Prince of Pride himself. He brought about the fall of the old world intentionally therefore the sin of greed is considered as fatal, if not more than, pride. They see the old world as a society of Pharisees who, instead of helping those in need, separated from them because they bothered their hearts.
Now that Egypt is finally in Coptic hands, we can use this momentous occasion to move the Papal seat back to its ancient home of Alexandria, ending the centuries long exile.

Mandaeism or Mandaeanism, also known as Sabaeanism , is a monotheistic and gnostic religion with a strongly dualistic cosmology. Its adherents, the Mandaeans, revere Adam, Abel, Seth, Enos, Noah, Shem, Aram, and especially John the Baptist. The name 'Mandaean' is said to come from the Aramaic manda meaning "knowledge". Within the Middle East, but outside of their community, the Mandaeans are more commonly known as the Subba or Sabians. The term Subba is derived from the Aramaic root related to baptism, the neo-Mandaic is Sabi. Occasionally, Mandaeans are called "Christians of Saint John".

Legends tell that during the reign of the Romans, Emperor Constantine was blessed by God to save his realm from the invading hordes of Goths and Turks. Many stories were told about this holy figure: some say that he united Europe under his rule after decades of division, others say that he sacrificed himself to save his people from the ravenous Turks. But one thing is certain, and that is on the day of his death, the Angels of the Lord turned him into a statue of marble and hid him under the depths of Constantinople. This is so that in the final days of the world, Constantine could awaken once more to lead the people of God onto salvation as their blessed and immortal emperor.

Neo-Huguenots believe that all rulers are in the service of God, and God only. Any ruler not deemed to serve God and the people are to be named tyrants, and overthrowing them is not only necessary, but a divine right. They believe that if every tyrant is removed from the face of the Earth, eternal prosperity will come to it, and so they try to go on grand campaigns to rid the world of these scum. Neo-Huguenots are heavily inspired by the Monarchomach theorists of pre-event France and consider tyrannicide to be a necessity in the fight for equality before God. They see feudalism as a tool for self-serving monarchs to consolidate more power for their selfish interests, so instead they follow a theocratic government where only the most pious and altruistic get to rule. The Queen of the Thelemites is considered to be the embodiment of a tyrant and her followers demon worshippers, and Novelists are known to have first brought back feudal law after the event, and so both are the main targets of Neo-Huguenot incursions. Catholics and other Protestants are both viewed with heavy distrust, as they both adhere to feudal structures and are also blamed for the destruction of the original Huguenots, a bitterness that never faded.

Neo-Donatists believe that the Last Judgement has come and the people of the world have been found lapse and unworthy of ascension. This means that all people on earth are stained by their sins and have been abandoned by God. The theology of this heresy ponders the implications of the event that destroyed the world of men identifying It, as many Christians did, with the Last Judgement. But in particular, adherents of this branch of Orthodoxy asked themselves if the apocalypse came to the world, why haven't the dead been resurrected and the rightful called at the right of the Father. There are different interpretations of why this happened: some believe that during the Event the apocalypse happened in full, the dead were revived and the children of God judged. What remains of the world today is nothing but the tortures of hell. Others believe that the Event has only heralded the apocalypse and the only reason why the dead haven't been resurrected is that the earth was so full of sin that God rebuked it. Thus, the world now exists as a limbo between the Judgement of God and the damnation of Hell.

A post event religion from across the Atlantic and near the Great Lakes, the Four Guardians faith has a deep connection to the cycles of the world and its natural power. Principally, there are only five truly divine beings in its cosmology, the Five Thunderbirds. The four lesser birds rule over each of the four winds and the greater Thunderbird, their father, rules over all creation. The four seasons of the year are ruled by four demi-gods - Paul Bunyan the Sower of Spring, Minne the Mistress of the Great River, Jack O'Lantern the Headless Bringer of Fall, and Father Christmas, who both rules over winter and delivers the Child, which is a representation of the new year being born following the battle between King Boreas and Vulcanus Rex.

The Aurorean faith is the disparate belief system of the coast and sea-dwelling Alaskans, spread widely across their homeland in the North Pacific, and varying wildly from city state to city state. The faith holds that there are three tiers of great spirits in their pantheon. The greater gods are aspects of Ellam Yua, the spirit of the universe, in the form of the Celestial Ram, the Earthly Ewe, and the Annointed Lamb, are beyond the mortal world of men and are the creators and orchestrators of the Earth, the sky, and all of life's symphonies. The lesser gods, such as the Raven and the Thunderbird, are those who live in the spirit world as mediators between the world of man and the world of gods, and control much of the earthly realm on the greater gods' behalf. Lastly are the various animistic spirits who inhabit the earth, sea, and sky, such as dwarfs and gnomes, and most importantly of all, the Aurorean Heavenly Host, a great army of spirits marching across the sky for which the religion is named. Aurorean shamans attempt to invoke the spirits for good luck, good weather, and bountiful seas, and the vast and elaborate creation stories of the frozen north are frequently retold at potlatches.

A faith hailing from the far shores of Greenland. The inhabitants of those regions adopted most of the beliefs of the Inuits, syncretizing them with the Christian faith. They believe in the sea trinity of Arnakuagsak, Sassuma Arnaa and Nerrivik, the three rulers of the sea. Other gods include the unnamed Røde Sømand, the stone-faced Qooqa and the great Martin Jaegeren, while the evil gods include the wrothful Adlet, the ferocious Amarok and the vengeful Tupilaq. Its followers give great importance to the act of hunting and the respect of the spirits.

column2: The Gallicanist Papacy was formed in the year 2205, with the last Patriarch of Québec proclaiming himself Pope Bien-Aimé I. The Québécois Patriarchate was one of many positions in the newly-formed Council of Patriarchs, meant to hold Catholicism together in total absence of papal contact. Claiming to have received an apparition from the Blessed Virgin, the now-Pope declared the old Papacy forfeit, and forced a massive schism in the Catholic Church of Canada, with many bowing to his word as the new Vicar of Christ, and many more denouncing him as a fraud and a heretic. Ultimately, the Gallicanist Church held its own in the aftermath of ecclesiastical controversy, spawning a new line of American Popes. Whether or not this neo-Catholic Church will survive the eventual backlash of old Catholicism to come its way remains to be seen.

Less a religion and more of a collection of philosophic ideas, Constitutionalism is the main doctrine by which the government of the United States operates under. Favoring a pragmatic mix of clemency and ruthlessness to achieve hegemony over the east coast of North America, Constitutionalists are applying their doctrine into their policies of governance to great effect.

Consisting of the remains of the Catholic Church in the United States, due to little to no contact with the Papacy in Rome, they resorted to self management under the newly formed Latin Patriarchate of Washington sponsored by the federal government. While the Latin Patriarch is no Pope, he is the highest Catholic religious authority on US soil.

A significant portion of American Protestants fall under Mainline Protestantism, rejecting Evangelicalism or Charismaticism, they stay true to the decentralist ideals of Protestantism and thus, have no religious authority.

The Levant has long been home to several Christian denominations,such as the Assyrian Church, Chaldean Catholics, and Oriental Orthodox. These churches had few or no theological differences, and were mostly distinguished by which Rite they used to celebrate the Liturgy. However, after the Event, these differences no longer seemed as significant as the need for cohesion and survival in the face of societal collapse, and so the Syriac Orthodox and Chaldean Catholic Churches joined together. This 'new' old Church is led by the Patriarch of Antioch and All the East.

With enough power and control of sufficient holy sites, a Stalinist ruler could declare themselves High Chairman - the supreme spiritual ruler to whom religious and political obedience is owed by all.

It has been many years since any single ruler held enough power to be considered the true Tsar of all the Russias. If we are able to unite the ancestral heartlands of Russia, we may be able to finally revive that august institution in truth.

Where Nobelians believe in the use of Knowledge for peace, Dynamiters consider it a mean to bring glory in battle. This fringe movement claims that war is the greatest of all arts of man, and endeavors to rebuild the great weapons of destruction that made humanity invincible. Following teachings that are believed to come from the great master of war they call the Merchant of Death, they will endeavor to bring back the glory of humanity's power of science, dedicating it to the art of war and destruction.

The Kalevalalaulu faith is an offshoot of ancient Finnish paganism which experienced a resurgence in the lands of Finland and Karelia in the years since the Event. Fusing traditional belief of the Sami, Finnish and Karelian people, the Kalevalalaulu faith is endemic to the region, and focuses more on protecting Finland, Karelia and the lands of the Sami, rather than expanding outwards. Yet, so far no conqueror has ever managed to take those northern lands, and all believers share the faith that it is thanks to the teachings of Ukko and Ilmatar and the bravery of their followers.

Russian folklore found a place to thrive in the post-Event world. Inspired by the tales of great heroes, from the bogatyrs of old Rodina to the campaigns of the Witcher-King, the Russian tundra over time developed a complex pantheon and belief system comprised of various deities and mythical creatures. The main deity is Trigolov, the Three-Headed God, who created the Earth by tricking Dyavol. The Earth is personified as Rodina, the mother goddess and creator of life. Other gods found in the prayers and altars of the far north include Veles, the god of witches and magicians, and Dazhbog, the Sun. Just as important as the gods are the folk heroes immortalised in the tales still told around bonfires, and to the tunes of bard songs. Figures such as Egoriy the Brave, who slew the cruel dragon Tugarin, or Ilya Muromets, who defeated the bandit Solovey, are prayed to for good luck, bravery, and guidance.

Gelugpa, or 'Yellow Hat' Buddhism is one of the traditional schools of Tibetan Buddhism and has absorbed many of the other schools in Tibet since the Event. It originated from Mahayana Buddhism,and retains many of its traditions,including an emphasis on Bodhisattvas and their intervention in the lives of believers. Traditionally,the Gelugpa are led by the Dalai Lama, but long ago the Panchem Lama was captured by the Chinese, preventing him from recognising the reincarnation of the next Dalai Lama. As a result, the traditional means of selecting the Dalai Lama was abandoned, and he is now elected by a council of Lamas from around Tibet.

Sanminzhuyi is a faith based around the teachings of the great Sapphire Didact found in the book "Principle of Minsheng". The Sapphire Didact rose to prominence in a great war the century before the event during this war 8 great armies of barbarians led by demonic lords arrayed themselves against the Middle Kingdom, slaughtering millions, forcing the Emperor of China to seek divine assistance from the Jade Emperor to fight off these hordes. The Jade Emperor granted his aid to the Middle Kingdom and raised 8 Great Generals to semi-divinity to fight back against the hordes. The Sapphire Didact proved himself to be the greatest of these generals and alongside the sly Ruby Chairman who saw himself raised to full divinity by the Jade Emperor as reward for saving China. However, the Jade Emperor himself had too shown his weakness by allowing these demons to grow so powerful to begin with, and through the wisdom of the Sapphire Didact he concluded that his continued reign would prove disastrous for his beloved China. As such with the assistance of the sly Ruby Chairman he overthrew the Jade Emperor and forced him into hiding for a time. However it would not be long until the Ruby Chairman showed his true colours and overthrew the Sapphire Didact through deceit and cunning, forcing him to retreat to Taiwan. From there he has gradually extended his influence back to the mainland and seeks to reclaim his beloved China for the betterment of all it's peoples and a return to the harmony of the universe.

Liehuo follows the teachings of the Heavenly Ruby Chairman, ruler of the Heavenly Mandate of all. Though once a man, the Chairman ascended to godhood to protect China from the Eight Armies of Evil and the Event to restore harmony to the world after the Jade Emperor was deposed. He fought alongside one of the Jade Emperor's most powerful warriors, The Sapphire Didact, against these eight armies of barbarians and demons. Following their victory these two turned on each other for the throne of heaven and the followers of the Sapphire Didact were banished to Taipei, he still insidiously plots from his island realm among his followers. The Chairman's teachings are left behind in the Red Book for them to follow, so that they might achieve righteousness and not fall to the lies of either the old Jade Emperor or the Deceiving Sapphire Didact. They strongly believe in the obligation to spread the Ruby Chairman's influence to the rest of the world especially the holdouts of the Jade Emperor and Sapphire Didact.

Daojiao is a polytheistic religion originating in China, by the 26th century it is isolated to solely southern China following the rise of Liehuo in the north. While traditionally regarded as founded by Laozi the Supreme Old Lord in the 4th century BC, some elements and practices can be traced to prehistoric folk religions across the Middle Kingdom. The followers revere Tao, the underlying natural order of the Universe – the active expression of Tao for an individual is Te, the inner virtue. Daojiao also value life over death, and believe it possible to achieve immortality, through various methods, including spiritual practices and alchemy. One of its most important dieties, the Jade Emperor, is believed to have been betrayed by two of his servants in the century prior to the event and remains in conflict with them to this day. These two servants were his two greatest generals in the fight against a horde of barbarians led by a series of Demon lords from beyond the middle kingdom, the barbarians and their demon lords proved too mighty for china to overcome without divine assistance. The Jade emperor granted it and lifted 8 generals to semi-divinity they protected china and their two greatest leaders, the Ruby Chairman and the Sapphire didact as they are now known, were raised even higher to the rank of full divinity. But they believed that the Jade Emperor had grown weak to allow these demons to grow so powerful and sought to overthrow him. The religions of Sanminzhuyi and Liehuo represent their followers, this series of events has upset the balance of the cosmos which cannot be restored unless both of these rebellious servants are brought to heel.

The Raven Tales are the creation myths of many of the indigenous groups of the American Northwest Coast. They speak of Raven, a supernatural shapeshifting trickster, who is said to be the creator of humanity and, in some myths, the world itself. One story speaks of how Raven stole the Sun, Moon, and stars from the Sky Chief, who was keeping it away from people. Another story says that Raven freed the first humans out of a clam. That being said, while he is often credited with creating the world and liberating humanity, Raven does not do things out of the goodness of his heart, but to satisfy his curiosity and boredom, being always hungry for vanity.\nOther gods also frequently make their appearance in the Raven Tales, such as the Ocean Woman, the goddess of fertility and abundance of fish in the sea, and the twin deities Ta'xet and Tia, who represent violent and peaceful death respectively. Killer whale spirits are considered rulers of the underworld and reincarnations of deceased ancestors. These Raven Tales are passed down during the potlatch, a ceremonial gathering held to mark important events, such as the birth of a child or passing of an elder.

The Jacobins, members of a secret society in the highest echelons of European academia, are those who live to placate the eternal hunger of Madame Guillotine. Jacobins believe that many years before the Event, the prophet Robespierre was given this sacred duty by the Madame herself, but was soon killed by those unbelievers who considered him a madman. With Madame Guillotine left unfed, it was humanity that paid the price, the Madame taking back all the lives owed to her in the Event. With rivers of blood painting the streets of Europe red, the Jacobins slowly reemerged and reorganised, seeking to right the wrongs of their ancestors. Though denounced by the Girondins from whom they branched out of, and driven underground by the many other faiths of the continent, the Jacobins have slowly built up a web of informants and volunteers in Europe's universities, and only need the right time to strike.

The Communards are those Girondins who reject the First Estate as the one given mandate by God. Instead, they believe a ruler cannot uphold his duties if he isn't even of the same Estate, and as such they believe the only Estate capable of ruling over the Third Estate is itself. Communards believe only the lowest echelons of society can uphold Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity, for they are the only ones who know what life is like without them. They also insist that Madame Guillotine will never be satisfied if she is fed the lives of those who have nothing to give, for it is the fat and the rich she yearns for. Thus, the Communards haven't only given themselves the noble goal of peasant liberation, but also believe it is their divine right to feed the whole of the First Estate to Madame Guillotine. As such, the Communards are heavily demonised and feared by the rulers and faiths of Europe, and rightfully so - for they have no compassion for the ruling classes and ask for none in return. When their turn comes, they will make no excuse for the terror to be unleashed.

The Church of Saint Tito, though having deep roots in the folk beliefs of the Balkans, had only recently been codified with the formation of Jugoslavija. For centuries after the Event, the states of the Balkans have suffered from wars and subjugation, just as they have many times before. In times like those, the disunited Catholic, Orthodox and Muslim peasants were briefly united in prayer towards a single mythical, shining hero - Marshal Tito. Ancient folk tales speak of the Prophet-Marshal, how he was directed by God himself to unite the squabbling tribes of the Balkans, and teach them the ways of Brotherhood and Unity. With the help of his great generals Jelachich and Karadjordje, Marshal Tito wrestled the vast plains of Pannonia from the tyrannical Ugars and the rolling hills of Raška from the hordes of Osman, and founded the first true Empire of Jugoslavija on the crossroads of Europe, guided by the principles of Brotherhood and Unity. The rebelling of the Yugoslavs against the hordes of Makedon, just as they have done many times before, has led to the codification of the many myths of Marshal Tito's heroism This led to the creation of a new holy book, one that reduces the roles of Jesus Christ and the Prophet Muhammad, and replaces them with the Prophet-Marshal as the true Messiah and the Seal of the Prophets, much to the chagrin of the people of Jugoslavija, who consider it a politicised perversion of their ancient faiths.

The Karmapa or 'Red Hat' school of Buddhism was once simply another form of Tibetan Buddhism, considered equally valid alongside the others. However, when the Chinese captured the Panchem Lama, they produced a new Panchem Lama, a Han Chinese man whom they claimed to be the true Lama (called 'the Red Lama' by Tibetans). Most Tibetans rejected this 'new Lama', but some accepted him. This led to a rift in the community, as it was no longer clear who the real Panchem Lama was, thus the traditional means of selecting the Dalai Lama could no longer be used. Those who followed the Red Llama came to be confused with the historical 'Red Hats' school, and now even the knowledge that there used to be another group called by this name has been forgotten.

Katerinist belief states that the Great Holy Spirit and Mother Russia are two equal aspects of the divine energy of the universe, one being masculine and the other feminine. They believe that while the Spirit created the world, Mother Russia created man, and in Her own image gave women the divine power of birth and motherly love. As such, they hold that, just as man is born from a woman, so too were great Russia, its golden age and its glory born from Catherine the Great, the Divine Mother. Katerinists claim that, while every Tsar is blessed by the Spirit, only the Tsarina-Mother was truly divine, and perfect evidence that women are the natural leaders of mankind. Contemporary Tsarists, however, do not believe that Mother Russia is a literal deity, believing the name to merely be a metaphor for the Great Holy Spirit.

A blend of Mongol nationalism and Tengri paganism, Khanism is the belief in the divinity of the great legendary hero Temujin, who in times past conquered the world and gained the title of 'Genghis Khan', or 'Universal Ruler'. Khanists believe that, at the height of his power, Temujin was betrayed by his friend, Han, and cast into the jaws of The Red Menace. Now, they ride ever onward over the plains, hoping to find the Red Menace's cave and free Temujin from his imprisonment.

Descendants of the antediluvian religious orders of Lutheranism, their organization and military history carried them through the times of turbulence and back into prominence. Requiring strict discipline of their followers and of the priests they recreated their bishoprics across the major kingdoms, which in turn flowed into the militaries and economies of the enterprising rulers. At the core of it all was the reconquest and reformation of the Archbishopric of Lund, who, while hotly contested by rival kings for control of them, seek to reassert their power of the faith as a whole.

Laestadianism is a pietistic movement within Lutheranism founded by pre-Event preacher Lars Levi Laestadius. Pietism places especial focus on individual piety and virtue, with Laestadianism advocating for a sinless, spiritual life, free from worldly vices and material greed. Simplicity and worldlessness are important in the every day life of Laestadians, with vanity being frowned upon, as a lavish lifestyle is considered sinful, as well as drinking, dancing, and bodily modifications. If knowingly sinned, a faithful believer should confess to another believer, so that his sins may be forgiven in Jesus' name and blood.

The Church of Enchanted Beings, named after the concept of "väsen", claims to be the successors of millennia old traditions of the European North. Though functionally Christian, centuries of distortion have rendered them a completely separate religion. Emphasis on oral traditions and folk stories have pushed its Biblical aspects into less and less importance, while belief in the supernatural and the hidden has become key parts of everyday life. The unifying part of this folklore is belief in hidden magical creatures, such as gnomes, trolls, and elemental spirits. Protector spirits and patron deities are also frequent and vary from region to region, of note is the presence of several severely distorted Aesir amongst the regional mythologies.

The Einblicker, or the "Insightful", are an esoteric movement that believes they hold the true history of the world. They adhere strongly to the god Adonis, who was created by Monad long before the age of man alongside his consort Dido. However, Adonis was killed and defeated by his brother Moloch, who sent unto the Earth many plagues and a Great Flood, and revealed himself to false prophets, masquerading as the true god. Under the guise of the One, Moloch demonised Adonis as the Devil, and through the faith of his followers kept control over the Earth for millennia. However, Adonis spent ages regaining his strength until finally retaking control of the Earth and defeating Moloch once and for all. In preparation for the great cataclysm to ensue, Adonis revealed himself to the true mystics and prophets of the world, such as Hermes Trismegistus and Christian Rosenkreuz - considered the Fathers of the Einblickers.\nThough the war in heaven caused great destruction on Earth, known to many as the Event, the true faith endured, its most faithful adherents now being delvers into what they consider the true nature of Monad and Adonis. They live without without strict moral code, believing the pleasures of life are gifts from Adonai and to suppress it is to succumb to Moloch's influence. The Einblickers especially revile what they consider the false churches of old, who still cling to the whims of Moloch, and aim to oppress the true faith. Thus, they seek to emulate the great hero Luther, who walked in the path of Hermann and fought to banish the forces of the Devil-Pope from the woods of the Teutons.

With obscure origins dating back to antediluvian missionaries from Western Europe, Eastern Protestantism is an amalgamation of various Protestant sects with Orthodoxy. Its congregation exists as a loose union of churches formed from the remnants of these ancient missionary activities. Despite the influences, Eastern Protestantism still maintains Orthodox traditions since its inception, and are preformed in the Byzantine Rite. Its adherents also share many commonalities Syriac and Chaldean Churches, which include religious calendars, festivals, and reverence of saints. At the same time, Eastern Protestants also revere Western Protestant figures like Lucas Cranach the Elder, Martin Luther, John Calvin, and Roger Williams.

The Ma'aravim, or the "Westerners" are an amalgam of Jewish sects in America, consisting of Reform, Masorati and Orthodox Jews. The Ma'aravim have long since integrated into the American system and thus are far removed from the affairs of old world Judaism. The Ma'aravim believe that the only way for the Messiah to eventually come is through 'repairing the world' through Tikkun Olam, a guideline to be righteous, kind and pious.

Originally hailing from eastern Europe, the Hasidic movement has found itself most prevalent in the United States. Initially part of the greater American Jewish community, in time, the Hasidic movement had effectively split from the rest of Ma'aravi Judaism and largely bases itself in more rural Jewish communities across the United States. While they agree about core principles of Hasidic Judaism, many sects have arose following the teachings of several important Rebbes.

The Sharifi school of thought is a sect of Islam from the Maghreb which has developed some heterodox beliefs, especially regarding who can be Caliph. In the chaos of the Post-Event world, many Muslims yearn for a Caliph to unite and defend the Ummah, but nobody has been strong enough and legitimate enough to do so in several hundred years. The Sharifi of Morocco, seeing the power of the Alaouite dynasty, came to believe that an Alaouite could become Caliph, even if he were not of the Quraysh tribe. This position has brought them into conflict with other Muslims, creating a rift in African Islam.

The Maronite Catholic Church is an Eastern Catholic church that has been in full communion with Rome for centuries. Though they use a different Rite to celebrate the Liturgy than Latin Catholics,they have no substantial theological differences,and thus enjoy good relations with each other. The Maronite Church exists primarily in Lebanon,and is led by the Patriarch of the Levant.

Founded by the prophet Mubarak, a scholar, adventurer, and now the Mahdi who found the truth on the history of the great Judges deep in the ancestral ruins of old Iraq. Mesopotamianism is internally considered an Islamic faith, but are denounced by the wider Islamic world as mushrikun - polytheists, for their reverence of ancestral Mesopotamian gods. Namely, the Mesopotamians revere figures such as Ishtar and Ea, whom they consider to be karubiyin loyal to Allah. They believe that these archangels, now carved into millennia old stones, guided old Mesopotamians before Islam. Under their guidance, the ancient Mesopotamians founded the Empire of Mesopotamia, which ruled the orient for millennia as the one true domain of Allah, until they were shattered by Iblis as revenge for being cast from heaven. The Mesopotamians now believe it is their destiny to restore the ancient empire as the one true ummah and usher in a new golden age.

First spread to India by Saint Thomas the Apostle over 25 centuries ago, the Nasrani sect of Christianity has always been a minority in India. With the chaos of the Event cutting India off from most outside communication, the various Nasrani Churches (both those in communion with the Pope and those in communion with the Eastern Church) united together for the sake of convenience. The example of several holy men has caused the Nasranis to grow in popularity over the last few decades, to the point where they are a majority in Kerala, in the southwestern coast of India, though they are still a minority overall.

Among those men, the greatest in all the fields of Knowledge were Nobel and his laureates, whose discoveries led humanity forward. However, the Merchant of Death always whispers in the hears of those willing to listen, and so it was that the glory of humanity also created great destruction, until the world was returned to the darkness of ignorance. The Nobelians struggle to return humanity to its former glory, believing they can recreate the greatness of the old world.

Originating in the distant and unknowable snowlands east of Russia, Razumism is a religion focused on the belief in a phenomenon known as "Mirovoy Razum" by which all human consciousness is thought to be linked. Razumists believe that this world mind is capable of altering human consciousness and the world. This is the origin of spirits with some being the human perspective of concepts and others being the impact humans have left on the collective mind after their death, enabling them to somewhat live on post death. They believe that the Event was caused by the uncontrolled collective mind growing restless and harming humanity. They believe that if humanity is to return to a pre-event stage of advancement it must first mature collectively.

It is believed that this entity is capable of influencing both human consciousness and the world. This is the origin of spirits with some being the human perspective of concepts and others being the impact humans have left on the collective mind after their death, enabling them to somewhat live on post death. The religion has been reformed and codified, with a unified set of beliefs and rituals.

Romuva is polytheistic, with a pantheon of gods led by Dievs, god of the sky. Other main gods include Perkunas, god of thunder and lightning, very similar to the ancient Scandinavian god Thor and the Slavic Perun. Other important deities include Saule, goddess of the sun and fertility, Daugava and Meness. After the Apocalypse this ancient religion underwent a renaissance in its number of followers until the majority of the Lithuania, Latvia and Western Belarus were followers of the faith. The Catholics of Nearby Poland could not stand for the heathenry which their once Lithuanian brothers had adopted and they led the charge in a crusade to wipe out the faith in Lithuania once more. By 2555 the religion exists only in a few isolated pockets, largely in secret given the Catholic faith which has reclaimed Lithuania.

Tengrism is the ancient traditional religion of the steppe people of Eurasia and the many people of Siberia, including various Turkic and Mongolic groups. The chief diety is Tengri, the creator god who rules the skies. Something to note is that this interpretation of Tengri is actually a misunderstanding by Muslim and Christian scholars. Tengri is infact less of a diety in the traditional sense and more so the universe, according to the followers of the faiths he is the land, the sky. the grass, the computer you are playing Crusader Kings 2 on right now, he is everything and the universe has a will that it expresses. Shamanism and animism are also a prominent feature in the religion. The religion survived the chaos of the event relatively unscathed in its isolated homelands however the Khanist religion spawned as an offshot in late 21st and early 22nd centuries. In the present day the Tengrist faithful of Eurasia are under threat from the Khanists to their south and the great merchantile empire of Vladivostok, both professing faiths which advocate for proselytisation. In game the various other shamanistic faiths of Siberia and the Steppe are also represented.
